document.title: An elemetary proof of an estimate for a number of primes less than the product of the first n primes
document.toctitle: An elemetary proof of an estimate for a number of primes …

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: Let α be a real number such that 1<α<2 and let =x0⁢x0α be a (unique) positive solution of the equation

Math.text: (x ^ (alpha - 1) - (pi / (e ^ 2 * square-root@(3))) * x) + 1 = 0.

abstract.p: Then we prove that for each positive integer >nx0 there exist at least nα primes between the +n1th prime and the product of the first +n1 primes. In particular, we establish a recent Cooke’s result which asserts that for each positive integer n there are at least n primes between the +n1th prime and the product of the first +n1 primes. Our proof is based on an elementary counting method (enumerative arguments) and the application of Stirling’s formula to give upper bound for some binomial coefficients.

document.note: 2010 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary 11A41, Secondary 11A51, 11A25. Keywords and phrases: Euclid’s theorem, infinitude of primes, product of the first n primes, Bonse’s inequality, Stirling’s formula.

para.p: Ever since Euclid of Alexandria, sometimes before 300 B.C., first proved that the number of primes is infinite (see Proposition 20 in Book IX of his legendary Elements [], mathematicians have amused themselves by coming up with alternate proofs. For more information about the Euclid’s proof of the infinitude of primes see e.g., [, p. 414, Ch. XVIII], and [, Section 1]. In [] the author of this article provided a comprehensive historical survey of different proofs of famous Euclid’s theorem on the infinitude of primes which has fascinated generations of mathematicians since its first and famous demonstration given by Euclid. Quite recently, in [] the author of this article presented a very short and elementary proof of Euclid’s theorem.

Euclid’s proof of the infinitude of primes is a paragon of simplicity: given a finite list of primes p1p2⁢…pn, multiply them together and add one. The resulting number, say =N⁢p1p2⋯pn, is not divisible by any prime on the list, so any prime factor of N is a new prime.
A modification of the above Euclid’s proof based on the factorization theorem can be found in author’s survey article [, p. 35, Section 4].

Notice that numerous proofs of the infinitude of primes yield anyone estimate for distribution of primes []. Applying Euclid’s proof presented above with -⁢p1p2⋯pn1 instead of +⁢p1p2⋯pn1, we obtain that <p+n1⁢p1p2⋯pn for each ≥n2, where pk is the kth prime. In 1907 H. Bonse [] gave an elementary proof of a stronger inequality, now called Bonse’s inequality (for a simple proof based on Erdős’ method [] see [, p. 238, Section 4.6]): if ≥n4, then

Math.text: (p _ (n + 1)) ^ 2 less p _ 1 * p _ 2 * cdots * p _ n

para.p: Bonse also proved that <p+n13⁢p1p2⋯pn for all ≥n5. In 2000 M. Dalezman [, Theorem 1] gave an elementary proof of stronger inequality <⁢p+n1p+n2⁢p1p2⋯pn with ≥n4. In 1960 L. Pósa refined firstly Bonse’s inequalities by proving that for every integer >k1 there is an nk such that <p+n1k⁢p1p2⋯pn for all >nnk. Further, a syntetic proof (i.e., one not involving the limit concepts of analysis) due to S. E. Mamangakis in 1962 [] for a theorem from which specialization lead to the following inequalities: <p⁢4n⁢p1p2⋯pn with ≥n11 and <p⁢4n4⁢p1p2⋯p-⁢4n9 with ≥n46. In 1971 S. Reich [] showed that for every positive integer k there exists a positive integer =n0⁢n0k such that <p+nk2⁢p1p2⋯pn for all ≥nn0. Furthermore, using a quite different approach from Bonse’s, in 1988 J. Sándor [] proved that for ≥n3, ≤+⁢p1p2⋯p-n1pnp-pn2⁢p1p2⋯pn and that for ≥n24, <+p+n52p/n22⁢p1p2⋯pn which is sharper than Bonse’s inequality (1).

On the other hand, using arguments of Analytic Number Theory, many authors have been obtained stronger inequalities than those mentioned above. In 1977 H. Gupta and S. P. Khare [] proved that <n2n⁢p1p2⋯pn for all ≥n1794. In 1983 G. Robin [, Théorème 4] proved that <nn⁢p1p2⋯pn for each ≥n13. Since by Stirling’s formula easily follows that ∼n2n⁢e-n1⁢2πnnn, it follows that the mentioned inequality by Gupta and Khare is stronger than those due to Robin. Motivated by a result of Gupta and Khare, in 2011 H. Alzer and J. Sándor improved their result [, Theorem]. Moreover, using some Rosser-Schoenfeld’s [] and Robin’s estimates [] for the prime counting function ⁢πx and Chebyshev function ⁢θx, in 2000 L. Panaitopol [] proved that <p+n1-n⁢πn⁢p1p2⋯pn for every ≥n2, where ⁢πx is the number of primes ≤x. This improves Pósa’s inequality in the following form: <p+n1k⁢p1p2⋯pn for ≥n⁢2k with given ≥k1. M. Hassani [] refined this inequality in 2006 by proving that for ≥n101 the exponent -n⁢πn can be replaced by ⁢-1/1logn-n⁢πn. Furthermore, using Panaitopol’s inequality, in 2009 S. Zhang showed [, Corollary 1] that <2p+n1⁢p1p2⋯pn for all ≥n10. This inequality yields an improvement of Pósa’s inequality [] given above and some Bonse-type inequalities. Furthermore, various Panaitopol-type inequalities and related limits are recently established by J. Sándor [] and J. Sándor and A. Verroken []).

Notice that Bonse’s inequality, all its refinemenets and improvements presented above does not guarantee the existence of “many primes” less than ⁢p1p2⋯pn. This is also the case with numerous known elementary proof of Euclid’s theorem on the infinitude of primes. For example, iterating the second Bonse’s inequality we find that <p+n2⁢p1p2⋯pn/43, which repeating still three times gives ≤p+n4⁢p1p2⋯pn/580729. This shows that for ≥n4 there exist at least 4 primes between the nth prime and the product of the first n primes. We see from the first Mamangakis’ inequality given above that for each ≥n11 there are at least ⁢3n primes between the nth prime and ⁢p1p2⋯pn. Notice also that the first Sándor’s inequality presented above and the well known estimation >pn⁢nlogn with ≥n5 (see e.g., [, (3.10) in Theorem 3]) imply that for each ≥n2 there are at least -⁢nlogn2 primes less than ⁢p1p2⋯pn. Quite recently in 2011, applying two simple lemmas in the Theory of Finite Abelian Groups related to the product of some cyclic groups Zm, R. Cooke [] modified Perott’s proof from 1881 ([], [, page 10]) to establish that there are at least n primes between the +n1th prime and the product of the first +n1 primes. Refining the Euler’s proof of the infinitude of primes presented below, in this note we improve Cooke’s result by proving the following Bonse-type inequality.
Theorem 1. Let α be a real number such that 1<α<2 and let =x0⁢x0α be a (unique) positive solution of the equation

Math.text: (x ^ (alpha - 1) - (pi / (e ^ 2 * square-root@(3))) * x) + 1 = 0.

p.text: Then for each positive integer >nx0 there exist at least nα primes between the +n1th prime and the product of the first +n1 primes.
Moreover, for each positive integer n there are at least n primes between the +n1th prime and the product of the first +n1 primes.

para.p: Remark. The first assertion of Theorem 1 can be shortly written in terms of the “little o” notation as

Math.text: p _ (o * n ^ 2) less p _ 1 * p _ 2 * cdots * p _ (n + 1)

para.p: as →n∞, where pk is the kth prime. However, our method applied for the proof of Theorem 1 cannot be applied for =α2; namely, this is because of the inequality (13) with =α2 is clearly satisfied for all ≥m1.

A computation via Mathematica 8 shows that <pn2pn2 for each ≥n5. Namely, it is well known (see e.g., []) that ∼pn⁢nlogn as →n∞, and so ∼pn2⁢n2log2n and ∼pn2⁢2n2logn. This immediately implies that ∼⁢2pn2⁢pn2logn. Notice also that using the known estimates -+lognloglogn/32</pnn<-+lognloglogn/12 with ≥n6 (see e.g., [, (3.10) and (3.11) in Theorem 3]) and a verification via Mathematica 8 for 1≤n≤1020, easily follows that >⁢2pn2⁢pn2logn for all ≥n1. Recall also that it is known that the sequence /pnlogn is strictly increasing (see e.g., [, p. 106]).

A motivation for our proof given in the next section comes from a less known proof of Euclid’s theorem due to Euler in 1736 (published posthumously in 1862 []; also see [, Sect. 135], [, p. 413] and citeme3) is in fact the first proof of Euclid’s theorem after those of Euclid and C. Goldbach’s proof presented in a letter to L. Euler in July 1730 (see [, p. 6] and [, Appendix C)]). As noticed in Dickson’s History [, p. 413] (see also [, page 80]), this proof is also attributed in 1878/9 by Kummer [] who gave essentially Euler’s argument. This Euler’s proof (see e.g., [, pp. 134–135], [] and [, page 3]; also cf. Pinasco’s proof []) is based on the multiplicativity of the φ-function defined as the number of positive integers not exceeding n and relatively prime to n. Namely, if p1p2…pn is a list of distinct ≥n2 primes with product P, then

The inequality (1) together with the definition of the φ-function says there exists at least an integer in the range 2P that is relatively prime to P, but such an integer has a prime factor necessarily different from any of the pk with =k12…n. This yields the infinitude of primes.

Theorem 1 may be considered as an extension of the above Euler’s result in order to obtain the estimate of a number of primes less than the product of the first n primes. Proof of Theorem 1 given in the next section is combinatorial in spirit and entirely elementary. It is based on some counting arguments by using Stirling’s formula to give upper bound for some binomial coefficients.

p.text: Let k and N be two arbitrary fixed positive integers, and let ⁢Nkn be the number of k-tuples x1…xk of nonnegative integers x1…xk is -+nk1k satisfying the inequality

Math.text: ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ k)@(x _ i) less= n
N * open-interval@(k, n) = binomial@(n + k, n)

para.p: For a fixed nonnegative integer m with 0≤m≤n, denote by ⁢Mkn the number of k-tuples x1…xk of nonnegative integers x1…xk such that
Then by induction no ≥k1 it is easy to prove the well known fact that =⁢Mkm-+mk1-k1 for each ≥k1. Hence, for such a fixed k we have

Math.text: N * open-interval@(k, n) = ((sum _ (m = 0)) ^ n)@(M * open-interval@(k, m)) = ((sum _ (m = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@((m + k) - 1, k - 1))

para.p: Next by induction on ≥n0, using the Pascal’s identity =+rir+i1+r1+i1 with 0≤i≤-r1, we immediately obtain that the sum on the right hand side of the above equality is equal to +nkk. Therefore, we have ⁢Nkn=+nkk=+nkn, as desired. ∎

p.text: Let α be a real number such that >α1. Then for each positive integer n

Math.text: (1 / nfactorial) * binomial@(n ^ alpha + n, n) less (e ^ (2 * n) * (n ^ (alpha - 1) + 1) ^ n * square-root@(3)) / (2 * n ^ (n + 1) * pi)

p.text: where a denotes the integer part of a. Furthermore, for all positive integers n we have

Math.text: (1 / nfactorial) * binomial@(2 * n, n) less (2 ^ (2 * n - 1 / 2) * e ^ n) / (n ^ (n + 1) * pi)

para.p: First observe that (3) holds for =n1. Stirlng’s asymptotic formula ≈!n⁢⁢2πn/nen as →n∞ is often presented in the following refined form due to H. Robbins []: (also see [])

Math.text: formulae@(formulae@(nfactorial = square-root@(2 * pi * n) * (n / e) ^ n * e ^ (gamma _ n), 1 / (12 * n + 1) less gamma _ n less 1 / (12 * n)), n = list@(1, 2, ldots))

para.p: Then applying (5) to all factorials !+nαn!nα!n, where -nα1<a:=nα≤nα we find that

Math.text: (1 / nfactorial) * binomial@(a + n, n) less (afactorial / (afactorial * nfactorial ^ 2)) * ((square-root@(2 * pi * (a + n)) * ((a + n) / e) ^ (a + n)) / (((square-root@(2 * pi * a) * (a / e) ^ a) cdot 2) * pi * n * (n / e) ^ (2 * n))) * e ^ (1 / (12 * (a + n)) - 1 / (12 * a + 1) - 2 / (12 * n + 1)) = (((e ^ n / (2 * n ^ (2 * n + 1) * pi)) * square-root@(1 + n / a)) cdot (1 + n / a) ^ a) * (a + n) ^ n * e ^ (1 / (12 * (a + n)) - 1 / (12 * a + 1) - 2 / (12 * n + 1))

para.p: Inserting the inequalities

Math.text: square-root@(1 + n / a) less square-root@(1 + n / (n ^ alpha - 1)) less square-root@(1 + n / (n - 1)) less= square-root@(3)

para.p: ≤+an+nαn,

Math.text: (1 + n / a) ^ a = (1 + n / a) ^ (a / n) ^ n less e ^ n

para.p: and
into inequality (6), we find that

Math.text: (1 / nfactorial) * binomial@(a + n, n) less (e ^ (2 * n) * square-root@(3) * (n ^ alpha + n) ^ n) / (2 * pi * n ^ (2 * n + 1)) = (e ^ (2 * n) * (n ^ (alpha - 1) + 1) ^ n * square-root@(3)) / (2 * n ^ (n + 1) * pi)

para.p: This proves (3). Finally, taking =an into (6) we immediately obtain (4). ∎

Math.text: f * x = (e ^ 2 * square-root@(3) * x ^ (alpha - 1) - pi * x) + 1

p.text: has exactly one positive root. Moreover, if =x0⁢x0α is this root, then f decreases on x0+∞.

para.p: The derivative of the function f is =⁢f′x-⁢e23-α1x-α2π whose a unique real root is =x1/⁢e23-α1π/1-2α. Therefore, in view of the fact that <-α20, we infer that f is decreasing on x1∞. However, since /⁢fx1x1=/⁢π-2α-α1>0 and so >⁢fx10, and =lim→x+∞⁢fx-∞, we conclude that there exists a unique positive root x0 of the function f. As >x0x1 we see that f decreases on x0+∞. ∎

First consider the case when 1<α<2. Then suppose that the assertion is not true. This means that there are an α with 1<α<2 and a positive integer m>x0=⁢x0α for which there are less than mα primes between the +m1th prime and the product of the first +m1 primes. For such a m, let 2=p1<3=p2<⋯<p+m1 be first +m1 consecutive primes. Accordingly, suppose that p+m2…p+m1k are all the primes between p+m1 and the product :=P⁢p1p2⋯p+m1 with ≤k-mα1. Then every positive integer less than P and relatively prime to P can be factorized as ⁢p+m2x1⋯p+mk1xk with nonnegative integers x1…xk. Then obviously we have

Math.text: (p _ (m + 1)) ^ (x _ 1 + cdots + x _ k) less (p _ (m + 2)) ^ (x _ 1) * cdots * (p _ (m + 1 + k)) ^ (x _ k) less P = p _ 1 * p _ 2 * cdots * p _ (m + 1) less (p _ (m + 1)) ^ (m + 1)

para.p: whence it follows that

Math.text: x _ 1 + cdots + x _ k less= m

para.p: Then by Lemma 1, a number ⁢Nkm of k-tuples x1…xk of nonnegative integers xi satisfying the inequality (7) is equal to +mkk. It follows that must be

Math.text: binomial@(m + k, m) >= varphi * P = (p _ 1 - 1) * (p _ 2 - 1) * cdots * (p _ (m + 1) - 1)

para.p: On the other hand, since ≥-pi1⁢2i for all ≥i5, it follows that for every ≥n3
Then (9) and (10) with n=m≥3 yield

Math.text: 2 ^ (m - 2) * (m + 1) less= (1 / mfactorial) * binomial@(m + k, m)

para.p: Using the fact that the sequence ↦k+mkm (=k12…) is increasing, the previous assumption <kmα and the inequality (3) of Lemma 2, we obtain that if ≥m3, then

Math.text: (1 / mfactorial) * binomial@(m + k, m) less (1 / mfactorial) * binomial@(m ^ alpha + m, m) less (e ^ (2 * m) * (m ^ (alpha - 1) + 1) ^ m * square-root@(3)) / (2 * m ^ (m + 1) * pi)

para.p: Now from (11) and (12) it follows that if ≥m3 then
or equivalently,

Math.text: m ^ (alpha - 1) + 1 > ((2 / e ^ 2) * nth-root@(m, (m * (m + 1) * pi) / (2 * square-root@(3)))) cdot m

para.p: Notice that the inequality (13) also holds for =m1 and =m2.
Since </π⁢231, it follows that

Math.text: nth-root@(m, (m * (m + 1) * pi) / (2 * square-root@(3))) > nth-root@(m, pi / (2 * square-root@(3))) >= pi / (2 * square-root@(3))

para.p: Substituting this into (13) we have

Math.text: (m ^ (alpha - 1) + 1) - (pi * m) / (e ^ 2 * square-root@(3)) > 0.

para.p: However, using the notations of Lemma 3, since >mx0 this lemma gives

Math.text: (m ^ (alpha - 1) + 1) - (pi * m) / (e ^ 2 * square-root@(3)) = f * m less f * x _ 0 = 0.

para.p: This contradicts (14), and hence the proof when 1<α<2 is finished.

It remains to prove the assertion for =α1. Then as in the previous case, suppose that for some ≥m1 there exist less than m primes between p+m1 and the product ⁢p1p2⋯p+m1. Then as in the previous case with the condition ≤k-m1 instead of ≤k-mα1, we arrive to the following inequality analogous to (11):

Math.text: formulae@(2 ^ (m - 2) * (m + 1) less= (1 / mfactorial) * binomial@(2 * m - 1, m) = ((1 / 2) cdot (1 / mfactorial)) * binomial@(2 * m, m), m = list@(1, 2, ldots))

para.p: Next from (15) and the inequality (4) of Lemma 2 for all ≥m1 we get
whence it follows that if ≥m6 then
A contradiction, and hence our assertion is true if ≥m6. We immediately verify that between p+n1 and the product ⁢p1p2⋯p+n1 there are at least n primes for all ∈n12345. This completes the proof. ∎

p.text: DEPARTMENT OF MATHEMATICS, MARITIME FACULTY KOTOR,
